channel.title: Harold Camping "flabbergasted"
channel.description:
http://news.yahoo.com/s/yblog_thelookout/20110523/ts_yblog_thelookout/doomsday-prophet-followers-flabbergasted-world-didnt-end
But the false prediction might not be so easily effaced from the lives of Camping's followers. The L.A. Times writes that Keith Bauer, a 38-year-old tractor trailer driver, took a road trip with his family to see the Grand Canyon before the world ended. "With maxed-out credit cards and a growing mountain of bills, he said, the rapture would have been a relief," the paper writes.
Or instead of maxing out credit cards and neglecting bills, he could have got off his lazy ass and went to work, instead of hoping that he wouldn't have to worry about them after he "ascended into the heavens". EDIT: Also, it doesn't look like they
scrubbed all mentions of the Judgment Day. The site previously featured a countdown clock to the May 21 rapture on its homepage.
http://familyradio.com/index2.html

item.title: Harold Camping "flabbergasted"
item.dc:creator: @m1lkman m1lkman
item.description:
@m1lkman wrote:

I did now. Very interesting.

Read full topic

item.title: Harold Camping "flabbergasted"
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

m1lkman:

So apparently Harold Camping was raptured but all of his followers and close friends weren’t. Wut?

Did you even read the article?

Read full topic

item.title: Harold Camping "flabbergasted"
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

He’s saying 200m Christians, not 200m people believed in the ‘judgement day’

Read full topic

item.title: Harold Camping "flabbergasted"
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Although, I just realized that

Camping's PR aide, Tom Evans, told the L.A. Times that the group is "disappointed" that [b]200 million[/b] true believers weren't lifted up to heaven on Saturday while everyone else suffered and eventually died as a series of earthquakes and famine destroyed the Earth.

That’s 2/3 of the US population. Not sure if the citation at the bottom means that the original number was changed in the article, or the number in the article needs to be changed…

Read full topic

item.title: Harold Camping "flabbergasted"

item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Idiotic Christians giving all Christians a bad name

Read full topic

@zyle1992 wrote:

http://news.yahoo.com/s/yblog_thelookout/20110523/ts_yblog_thelookout/doomsday-prophet-followers-flabbergasted-world-didnt-end

But the false prediction might not be so easily effaced from the lives of Camping's followers. The L.A. Times writes that Keith Bauer, a 38-year-old tractor trailer driver, took a road trip with his family to see the Grand Canyon before the world ended.

“With maxed-out credit cards and a growing mountain of bills, he said, the rapture would have been a relief,” the paper writes.

Or instead of maxing out credit cards and neglecting bills, he could have got off his lazy ass and went to work, instead of hoping that he wouldn’t have to worry about them after he “ascended into the heavens”.

EDIT: Also, it doesn’t look like they

scrubbed all mentions of the Judgment Day. The site previously featured a countdown clock to the May 21 rapture on its homepage.
